discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In Splunk, you cannot create a new index directly from the Data Inputs settings. Instead, indexes are created from:

Settings â†’ Indexes (in Splunk Web UI)
indexes.conf file (for manual configuration)

Data Inputs settings allow you to configure how data is collected but do not provide an option to create new indexes.

Selected Answer: B
You can create a new index in the Data Input settings in Splunk. When configuring a data input, you have the option to select an existing index or create a new one if needed

Answer is B=Yes. If the index you want to send the data to isn't in the list and you have permissions to create indexes, you can create a new index by clicking the Create a new index button.https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/SplunkCloud/8.2.2203/Data/Modifyinputsettings( Store an event in an index)

Selected Answer: A
I would say No. 
Adding new index is under "Indexes" of General "Input" Menu
However, under "Data Input" Settings , you cannot create new Index.

1. Click on the "Settings" link in the top navigation menu.
2. In the Settings page, under the "Data" section, click on "Indexes" to access the Indexes settings.
3. On the Indexes page, you will see a list of existing indexes. To create a new index, click on the "New Index" button.

So the answer is YES
I would say "No" but , you can create a new index in Settings--> Indexes or when you upload a file via Upload/monitor then you can create a new index

comments.content: Ignore the previous comment , I tested it and YES , you can add new index

questions.question_text: You are able to create new Index in Data Input settings.
Splunk Parses data into individual events, extracts time, and assigns metadata.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
plunk parses data into individual events, extracts the timestamp, and assigns metadata to each event. This process allows Splunk to index and search events based on their time of occurrence and other metadata
correct, page 59

questions.question_text: Which of the statements is correct regarding click and drag option in timeline?

choices.A: The new result after selecting the range by dragging filters the events and displays the most recent first.
choices.D: This doesn't execute a new query.
choices.B: There is no functionality like click and drag in Splunk's timeline.
choices.C: Using this option executes a new query.

discussion.content: A would be wrong here because it says "new result" which implies a new search or query was run, which is incorrect. D is only answer

Selected Answer: D
D seems to be correct

So, basically nothing happens by clicking and dragging by itself, it just selects the bars and makes the options "Zoom to Selection" or "Deselect" available.
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/SplunkCloud/latest/Search/Usethetimeline

Selected Answer: D
Clicking and dragging will not execute a new search. The answer is D
D is correct
D is correct. Page 67 of the PDF
Tecnhincally D is correct too.
correct, page 64

questions.question_text: Which symbol is used to snap the time?
Which of the statements are correct? (Choose three.)

choices.D: Zoom-Out: Expands the time focus and doesn't re-executes the search.
choices.C: Format Timeline: Hides or shows the timeline in different views.
choices.A: Zoom to selection: Narrows the time range and re-executes the search.
choices.E: Zoom-out: Expands the time focus and re-executes the search.
choices.B: Zoom to selection: Narrows the time range and doesn't re-executes the search.

discussion.content:
ACE :
page 68 of the PDF : both "Zoom Out" and "Zoom to Selection" "re-executes the search"
Correct answer is B,C,D
100% ACE just tested it. Dragging the timeline however doesn't re execute the search
BCD should be the answer
BCD. no actions taken on the timeline, be it zooming in or out, or clicking and dragging will re-execute the search. so A and E are disqualified as possible answers.
